article.title: nIFTy Cosmology: the clustering consistency of galaxy formation models

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 show about the orphan fraction in different galaxy formation models?
choices: The fraction of orphan satellites is independent of stellar mass.
Models that track orphan trajectories tend to have higher orphan fractions at low masses.
GALACTICUS and GALFORM consistently show the lowest orphan fractions.
Models that track orphan trajectories tend to have lower orphan fractions at low masses.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information can be inferred from the similar slopes of the mean halo occupation number for satellite galaxies at larger masses in Figure 2?
choices: Different galaxy formation models predict similar numbers of central galaxies.
The mass definition used for haloes has a significant impact on the results.
Galaxy formation models distribute satellite galaxies in haloes in a similar way.
Orphan galaxies do not contribute significantly to the mean halo occupation number.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 compares the mean halo occupation number for different galaxy types. What key difference is observed between HOD and SAMs in the bottom panels showing orphan satellites?
choices: SAMs show a much steeper slope, indicating orphan satellites populate massive haloes more often.
HOD models show a much steeper slope, indicating orphan satellites populate massive haloes more often.
Both models show similar trends, indicating no significant difference in their treatment of orphan satellites.
The differences in the mean halo occupation number for orphan satellites are negligible at all masses.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 displays the radial distribution of galaxies. What do the flatter radial distributions of SAGE and GALICS 2.0, compared to other models, indicate?
choices: These models overpredict the number of orphan satellites at all radii.
The radial distribution of galaxies is insensitive to the treatment of orphan satellites.
These models demonstrate the contribution of non-orphan satellite galaxies to the radial distribution.
HOD models are more accurate in reproducing the radial distribution of galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the good agreement of the 2PCF for central galaxies in Figure 5 imply about the different galaxy formation models?
choices: They predict very similar clustering properties for central galaxies despite different implementations.
The models have been calibrated using the same set of observational constraints.
The scatter in the 2PCF at small scales is solely due to the treatment of orphan satellites.
The models are insensitive to the mass definition used for dark matter haloes.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6 examines the 2PCF for different galaxy types. What significant difference is observed between HOD and SAMs in the bottom panels showing orphan satellites?
choices: SAMs exhibit a lower clustering amplitude than HOD models, particularly at small scales.
HOD models exhibit a lower clustering amplitude than SAMs, particularly at small scales.
Both SAMs and HOD models show consistent clustering amplitudes for orphan satellites.
The differences in the 2PCF for orphan satellites are solely due to their different radial distributions.
